What is Acceleration?

If the Contractor is prevented from following what was its reasonable plan at the time of entering the Contract for carrying out the Works or a part of them (i.e., disturbance, hindrance or interruption to the Contractor’s normal Working hours or the Works were



disrupted), the likelihood is that the Contractor resources will accomplish lower productivity or efficiency than Planned on the impacted Work activities, such that overall, those Work activities will cost more to complete.

Hence, the Work that is carried with a lower than reasonably anticipated Productivity rate (i.e., which is disrupted) will lead to

Activity delay

The need for acceleration, such as increasing resources, work faces or working hours, to avoid activity delay

Or combination of both

Delay and Disruption are inherently interrelated. A loss in Productivity (i.e., disruption) can lead to delay and, if the impacted activities are on critical path, that can be a critical delay.

It is possible for work to be disrupted and yet to be completed by the contract completion date. In this situation, the Contractor will not have claim for EOT, but it may have a claim for the cost of the lost productivity.

Equally, delay can lead to disruption. If the Contractor has less time to carry out the work activities (absent an EOT for the critical path activities), it is possible that acceleration measures implemented will lead to those tasks being carried out with lower productivity than planned and hence at greater cost.

Acceleration Measures taken by the Contractor

During the execution of the Project, the Contractor encountered multiple delays that were Employer delay events and not attributable to the Contractor.

These delays collectively impacted the Project completion date and created the risk of missing the agreed completion date. The Contractor under clause 4.3.8.2.4 of Scope of Work notified the Employer regarding the ‘Major issues and areas of concerns’ in the Daily Progress reports.

Such compensation shall be subject to such substantiation of the Contractor's costs as Company may reasonably require and, to the extent possible, be calculated in accordance with the Rates.” 

The Contractor under clause 15.1 of General conditions of the Contract is entitled to additional costs for such remedial measures taken on proper substantiation to the Employer/ Company.
